title: BBC Question Time: Mum hailed as 'icon' over impassioned speech on son's racist abuse

A mum has been hailed as a BBC Question Time's icon after delivering an impassioned speech on her son's racist abuse.

The audience member said her second-generation son has been called a 'p***', years after she was called 'curry face' at school.

She made her moving speech during a discussion about the racist taunting of English football players during the side's Euro 2020 qualifier against Bulgaria on Monday.

The mother said: "My son was attacked, even though he's the second generation.

"He was attacked and he was called a p***. Now you tell me, how does a person take a p***? What do we say?

"White supremacy, that's how we feel. I was born in this country, my father served in this country, but it is white supremacy that is dividing everybody.

"I don't like being called a w**, I'm a human being. I went to school, I used to be called curry face. Is that a name? That's disgraceful, I don't like it.

"We have to abolish all this race hate, colour hate. Everyone here has the same amount of bones, the same amount of blood.

"You take my skin off and we are exactly the same. Where has racism come from?"

The audience member says she has taught her son, who works in security, that he is a 'human being' and not a label.

The woman was applauded by the audience and all of the panelists at the end of her rant.

Twitter users also backed the mum, sharing their similar experiences of abuse.

One person tweeted: "She’s right, stop the dehumanising of people and we’ll begin to have more tolerance.

"We’re all on the same journey through life. It’s only the right wing beliefs of cultures that cause the trouble."

Christopher Darby added: "I saw this lady and was so moved.

"The p word she used, thankfully I have not heard that filthy word used since I grew up in the 1970s and 1980s.

"I am horrified it is still in use. Anyone uttering it should be arrested for hate crime."
